results.title: Applying ethical principles for artificial intelligence in regulatory reform
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: The report considers core ethical principles and assess their implications and challenges, to assist stakeholders in adopting best practices in incorporating the principles in the development, deployment and usage of the AI systems.

results.title: Computer output as evidence : final report, Dec. 2004
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This final report consolidates the findings and responses that were received by the Technology Law Development Group for its consultation paper entitled "Computer output as evidence" published in September 2003.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on opinion evidence, Oct. 2011
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report presents the Law Reform Committee's observations of and  recommendations to amend section 47 of the Evidence Act.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on Online Gaming and Singapore, July 2010
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report prepared by the Law Reform Committee on Online Gaming and Singapore discusses the differences between online gaming and online gambling. It also highlights the ambiguities in the existing laws in Singapore concerning online gaming and online gambling.

results.title: Report on the 1996 Hague Convention on the Protection of Children, Aug. 2017
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report on the 1996 Hague Convention on the Protection of Children presents an introduction, the rationale for cooperation and some practical aspects concerning implementation. It ends with a summary and some recommendations.

results.title: Rethinking database rights and data ownership in an AI world
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report analyses the legal issues regarding the control/rights over the "big data" databases in the new and emerging Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies, and to ensure data contributor's retaining appropriate level of control and access to the data. It also provides recommendations on copyright protection of computer-generated works.

results.title: The impact of the regulatory framework on e-commerce in Singapore : symposium, Technology Law Development Group, Singapore Academy of Law, 5 April 2002
authors: Symposium on the Impact of the Regulatory Framework on E-Commerce in Singapore (2002 : Singapore)
abstracts: The Technology Law Development Group organised "The impact of the regulatory framework on e-commerce in Singapore" symposium on 5th April 2002. This publication is a record of the symposium proceedings, of the dialogue and discussion on the legal and policy challenges facing Singapore e-commerce's industry.

results.title: Loss of inheritance or savings : a proposal for law reform, Apr. 2008
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This is a proposal for legislative reform concerning loss of inheritance or savings. It provides information on the legal background, need for reform and possible consequences of legal reform.

results.title: Report  of the Law Reform Committee on Pre- and Post-Judgment Interest, Aug. 2005
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report contains the recommendations of the law reform sub-committee which was set up at the request of the Chief Justice Yong Pung How to review the law on pre-and post-judgment interest. It reviews the current practice of the courts in awarding interest, issues of pre-judgment interest, post-judgment interest generally, as well as post-judgment interest in respect of foreign currency, and interest running on foreign judgments and arbitral awards.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on Ancillary Orders after Foreign Divorce or Annulment, July 2009
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report prepared by the Law Reform Committee on ancillary Ancillary Orders after Foreign Divorce or Annulment presents the Committee's proposal that the Singapore court should have the power to order financial relief after a foreign divorce or annulment of marriage or legal separation.

results.title: Isu-isu wasiat, faraid & harta pusaka di Singapura
abstracts: Ini adalah sebuah buku oleh Suhaimi Salleh yang mengandungi kompilasi 30 rencana yang pernah disiarkan dalam Berita Harian/Berita Minggu di ruangan Wasiat & Faraid.

results.title: ACRA & I : being an effective director
authors: Singapore. Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority
abstracts: This handbook was written from a regulator's perspective for those intending to be a director and for those who have no formal training on running a company. This book aims to assist companies and their directors understand their various obligations better and to enable them to fulfill their regulatory responsibilities.

results.title: Report on Law of Part Payments and Deposits, Dec. 2015
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report on Law of Part Payments and Deposits provides an introduction of the law. It also includes issues and questions related to the law.

results.title: Consultation paper on certain issues concerning arbitration-related court proceedings, Jan. 2018
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This is a consultation paper on issues relating to costs in arbitration-related court proceedings.

results.title: Proposals for amending the Building and Construction Industry Security of Payment Act, Sept. 2015
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This contains proposals for amending the Building and Construction Industry Security of Payment Act. It provides the background of the Act and includes suggestions for legislative revision.

results.title: Report on proposed legislation to curb stalking
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report by the Law Reform Committee recommends that: stalking should be made a criminal offence in Singapore; sentencing court should be able to make a prohibition order to prevent further unlawful stalking; integrated means by which an expedited (temporary protection) order can be obtained.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on Reform of Admissibility of Hearsay Evidence in Civil Proceedings, May 2007
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This is a report of the Law Reform Committee on Reform of Admissibility of Hearsay Evidence in Civil Proceedings chaired by Mr Philip Jeyaretnam. It looks into various aspects of the Evidence Act including reform options, possible models for Singapore and safeguards.

results.title: Discussion paper of the Sub-Committee on Civil Law and Civil Proceedings
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This is a discussion paper on limitation periods for latent damage by the Law Reform Sub-Committee on Civil Law and Civil Proceedings, on limitation periods for personal injury cases and non-personal injury cases. Includes a draft Bill on making changes to the Limitation Act (Cap 163).

results.title: The United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (Vienna, 1980) : should Singapore ratify?
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: Consultation with business organisations indicate they are in favour of ratifying the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods, and this report presents the reasons and advantages for the recommendation of ratification. Includes a comparison of the provisions of the Convention with Singapore laws in tabular form.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on the Hague Convention on Choice of Court Agreements 2005, Mar. 2013
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report prepared by the Law Reform Committee on the Hague Convention on Choice of Court Agreements 2005 presents the Committee's recommendations on whether Singapore should adopt the Convention.

results.title: Discussion paper on liability for negligently inflicted psychiatric illness
abstracts: This discussion paper examines if reform is required to the law relating to liability in negligence for psychiatric illness unconnected with any physical injury.

results.title: Paper on reforms to the law of restitution on mistakes of law
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This paper identifies and discusses the relevant issues and the areas for reform of the law concerning recovery based on payments made under a mistake of law. It includes a draft Bill for recommendations for reform by the Law Reform Committee.

results.title: Report of the Sub-Committee on the Status of Children Born Through Artificial Conception
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report concludes that the status of children born through artificial conception is as much in doubt and subject to uncertainty in statutory law as it is in the common law, and recommends that legislation be proposed to clarify the status of children born through medically assisted reproductive procedures.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on limitation periods in private international law, Jan. 2011
authors: Law Reform Committee, Singapore Academy of Law
abstracts: This report prepared by the Law Reform Committee on limitation periods in private international law presents the Committee's recommendations to reform the law on the application of foreign limitation periods.

results.title: Taking of statements by law enforcement agencies
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This is the final report by the Law Reform Sub-Committee for Criminal Procedure & Evidence on identifying the problem areas on the practice of statement taking by law enforcement officers, and proposal of solutions.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on the Review of the Parol Evidence Rule, Nov. 2006
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report sets out the observations and recommendations of the LRC Subcommittee on the Review of the Parol Evidence Rule. It ends with the Subcommittee's proposal for amendments.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on Reforming Legal Professional Privilege, Oct. 2011
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report prepared by the Law Reform Committee on Reforming Legal Professional Privilege presents the Committee's recommendations on whether the statutory rules of legal professional privilege contained in the Evidence Act can be applicable to affidavits presented to the court.

results.title: Report of the Law Reform Committee on Right to Judicial Review of Negative Jurisdictional Rulings, Jan. 2011
authors: Singapore Academy of Law. Law Reform Committee
abstracts: This report prepared by the Law Reform Committee on Right to Judicial Review of Negative Jurisdictional Rulings presents the Committee's proposals to call for a right to judicial review of negative jurisdictional rulings made by arbitral tribunals in arbitrations governed by the International Arbitration Act (Cap 143A, 2002 rev ed).

results.title: Report on certain issues concerning costs in arbitration-related court proceedings
abstracts:
This report, produced by the Costs in Arbitration-Related Court
Proceedings Subcommittee, addresses the issue of how the court should approach the question of cost in arbitration-related court proceedings. The Subcommittee recommends that the "Guide for the Conduct of Arbitration Originating Summons", issued by the Registrar of the Supreme Court, be amended to require the filing of costs schedules, and that parties apply for the appointment of cost-assessors to help determine costs.

results.title: Women in Singapore : your rights and status
authors: Association of Women for Action and Research
abstracts: This is a book published by the Association of Women for Action and Research (AWARE), seeks to mainstream the Convention of Elimination of all forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) as a framework.

results.title: Bribery abroad : lessons from the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
abstracts: This book, written by Richard L. Cassin, a lawyer, started out from the FCPA Blog, which reports news about the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), as well as bribery and corruption cases. The blog seeks to put information on the statute, as well as its enforcement, in an informal setting.

results.title: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977 & Lay person's guide to FCPA & Federal Sentencing guidelines - chapter 8, part B
abstracts: With the ten-fold increase in the enforcement of anti-corruption law in the United States, more people are paying attention to the United States Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977. This book contains the original words of the FCPA, as well as a short and understandable explanation of the FCPA's provisions.

results.title: Consumer Protection (Consumer Goods Safety Requirements) Regulations (CGSR) : information booklet
abstracts:
This information booklet serves as a guide to the Consumer Protection (Consumer Goods Safety Regulations) Regulations 2011 (CGSR). It also provides a nonexhaustive
list of applicable safety standards for respective product categories as a reference.

results.title: Drugs law and legal practice in Southeast Asia : Indonesia, Singapore and Vietnam / Tim Lindsey and Pip Nicholson.
abstracts: "Drugs Law and Legal Practice in Southeast Asia investigates criminal law and practice relevant to drugs regulation in three Southeast Asian jurisdictions: Indonesia, Singapore and Vietnam. These jurisdictions represent the spectrum of approaches to drugs regulation in Southeast Asia, highlighting differences in practice between civil and common law countries, and between liberal and authoritarian states. This book offers the first major English language empirical investigation and comparative analysis of regulations, jurisprudence, court procedure, and practices relating to drugs law enforcement in these three states."--Bloomsbury Publishing.

results.title: Legal rights : the guide for deaf and hard of hearing people / National Center for Law and Deafness.
abstracts: Authors, Sy DuBow, Sarah Geer, Karen Peltz Strauss.
Revised edition of: Legal rights of hearing-impaired people / National Center for Law and the Deaf. 3rd ed. 1986.
Includes bibliographical references and index.
digitized. 2010. HathiTrust Digital Library. committed to preserve. pda. MiAaHDL.
Electronic reproduction. [S.l.] : HathiTrust Digital Library, 2010. MiAaHDL.

results.title: Contemporary Islamic law in Indonesia : Sharia and legal pluralism / Arskal Salim.
abstracts: Indonesia has probably the fastest changing legal system in the Muslim world. This ethnographic account of legal pluralism in the post-conflict and disaster situation in Aceh addresses changes in both the national legal system and the regional legal structure in the province. Focusing on the encounter between diverse patterns of legal reasoning advocated by multiple actors and by different institutions (local, national and international; official and unofficial; judicial, political and social cultural) it considers the vast array of issues arising in the wake of the December 2004 earthquake an.

results.title: Investor and industry perspectives on investment advisers and broker-dealers [electronic resource] / Angela K. Hung ... [et al.].
abstracts: In theory, financial professionals are relatively distinct: A broker conducts transactions in securities on behalf of others; a dealer buys and sells securities for his or her own accounts; and an investment adviser provides advice to others regarding securities. Broker-dealers and investment advisers are subject to different regulatory structures. But trends in the financial services market since the early 1990s have blurred the boundaries between them. Regulatory reform requires a clearer understanding of the industry's complexities. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission asked RAND to conduct this study to examine the professionals' current business practices and whether investors understand differences between and relationships among them. The report describes a heterogeneous industry, with firms taking many different forms and offering a multitude of services and products and with investors failing to distinguish broker-dealers and investment advisers along regulatory lines. Despite this, investors express high levels of satisfaction with the services they receive from their own financial service providers. This satisfaction was much more frequently reported to arise from the personal attention the investor receives than from the actual financial returns arising from this relationship.

results.title: Authoritarian rule of law [electronic resource] : legislation, discourse, and legitimacy in Singapore / Jothie Rajah.
abstracts: Revised version of thesis (Ph.D.)--University of Melbourne, Melbourne Law School, 2010, issued under the title Legislating illiberalism.
Includes bibliographical references (p. 299-331) and index.

results.title: The legal and regulatory aspects of Islamic banking [electronic resource] : a comparative look at the United Kingdom and Malaysia / Abdul Karim Aldohni.
abstracts: "During the last ten years the Islamic banking sector has grown rapidly, at an international level, as well as in individual jurisdictions including the UK. Islamic finance differs quite substantially from conventional banking, using very different mechanisms, and operating according to a different theory as it is based on Islamic law. Yet at the same time it is always subject to the law of the particular financial market in which it operates. This book takes a much-needed and comprehensive look at the legal and regulatory aspects which affect Islamic finance law, and examines the current UK and international banking regulatory frameworks which impact on this sector. The book examines the historical genesis of Islamic banking, looking at how it has developed in Muslim countries before going on to consider the development of Islamic banking in the UK and the legal position of Islamic banks within English law. The book explores company, contract, and some elements of tax law and traces the impact it has had on the development of Islamic banking in the UK, before going on to argue that the current legal and regulatory framework which affects the Islamic banking sector has on certain occasions had an unintended adverse impact on Islamic banking in the UK. The book also provides an overview of the Malaysian experience in relation to some of the main legal and regulatory challenges in the context of Islamic banking and finance"--Provided by publisher.

The contributions include detailed analyses of some of the most visible issues, including intellectual property, security, privacy, and censorship.

results.title: Shari'a and Social Engineering [electronic resource] : The Implementation of Islamic Law in Contemporary Aceh, Indonesia / R. Michael Feener.
abstracts: This book seeks to open new lines of discussion about how Islamic law is viewed as a potential tool for programs of social transformation in contemporary Muslim society. It does this through a critical examination of the workings of the state shari'a system as it was designed and implemented at the turn of the twenty-first century in Aceh, Indonesia. While the empirical details of these discussions are unique, this particular case presents a remarkable site for investigating thebroader issue of the impact of instrumentalist, future-oriented visions of Islamic law on modern Muslim calls for the.

results.title: Constitutional dialogue in common law Asia / Po Jen Yap.
abstracts: Constitutional dialogue is a distinct form of institutional interaction whereby the pursuit of legislative goals can be constructively altered, but not foreclosed, by judicial input into the lawmaking process. Even though the respective constitutions of Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Singapore do not provide for structural devices that enable the local legislatures to reverse a constitutional decision, except via a constitutional amendment, their courts can and do apply dialogic canons of interpretation that can foster a debate with the political branches of government. Dialogic review is also more politically efficacious in common law Asia as each of the three territories has been governed by the same ruling party or coalition since decolonization and will continue to be so governed for the foreseeable future. Where the judiciary operates within a constitutional system dominated by a semi-permanent party or coalition in government, the pursuit of dialogic review is also the political expedient way for courts to engage in a valuable but less confrontational colloquy with the political institutions on the requisites of a constitutional democracy. In making a case, the book draws on the history and constitutional frameworks of Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Singapore; and explores how dialogic review can be applied to four core constitutional concerns: freedom of expression, freedom of religion, right to equality, and criminal due process rights.

While the empirical details of these discussions are unique, this particular case presents a remarkable site for investigating thebroader issue of the impact of instrumentalist, future-oriented visions of Islamic law on modern Muslim calls for the.

abstracts: Asks whether environmental law and policy in developed countries can be successfully transferred to developing countries. This book questions whether developing countries are indeed ready and able to implement various ideas from the developed world, such as integration of environmental law, and use of market-oriented instruments.

abstracts: "During the last ten years the Islamic banking sector has grown rapidly, at an international level, as well as in individual jurisdictions including the UK. Islamic finance differs quite substantially from conventional banking, using very different mechanisms, and operating according to a different theory as it is based on Islamic law. Yet at the same time it is always subject to the law of the particular financial market in which it operates. This book takes a much-needed and comprehensive look at the legal and regulatory aspects which affect Islamic finance law, and examines the current UK and international banking regulatory frameworks which impact on this sector. The book examines the historical genesis of Islamic banking, looking at how it has developed in Muslim countries before going on to consider the development of Islamic banking in the UK and the legal position of Islamic banks within English law. results.title: Fair, square & legal : safe hiring, managing & firing practices to keep you & your company out of court / Donald H. Weiss.
abstracts: Fair, Square & Legal is a concise, one-stop guide to what you as a manager should and shouldn't do if you want to stay clear of trouble. This revised edition has been thoroughly updated throughout, and provides new coverage of the Family and Medical Leave Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1991, and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Written by an experienced manager, the book translates complex legal issues and precedents into a set of easy-to-follow guidelines for managing people. It provides both an overview of safe managerial procedures and a quick look-up source for specific situations you may encounter. The book encompasses a broad range of potential problem areas. For each, author Donald H. Weiss supplies non-legalese definitions of key terms, practical guidelines for what to say and do, fictionalized stories that illustrate both problems and solutions, and actual case studies of precedent-setting court decisions.

results.title: Who owns you? : the corporate gold-rush to patent your genes / David Koepsell.
abstracts: Who Owns You? is a comprehensive exploration of the numerous philosophical and legal problems of gene patenting.; Provides the first comprehensive book-length treatment of this subject.; Develops arguments regarding moral realism, and provides a method of judgment that attempts to be ideologically neutral.; Calls for public attention and policy changes to end the practice of gene patenting.

results.title: Fish in the lakes, wild rice, and game in abundance : testimony on behalf of Mille Lacs Ojibwe hunting and fishing rights / James M. McClurken, compiler ; with Charles E. Cleland [and others].
abstracts: "On 13 August 1990 members of the Mille Lacs Band of Ojibwe filed a lawsuit against the State of Minnesota for interfering with the hunting, fishing, and gathering rights that had been guaranteed to them in an 1837 treaty with the United States. In order to interpret the treaty the courts had to consider historical circumstances, the intentions of the parties, and the treaty's implementation. The Mille Lacs Band faced a mammoth challenge.
How does one argue the Native side of the case when all historical documentation was written by non-Natives? The Mille Lacs selected six scholars to testify for them.

Published here for the first time, Charles Cleland, James McClurken, Helen Tanner, John Nichols, Thomas Lund, and Bruce White discuss the circumstances under which the treaty was written, the personalities involved in the negotiations, and the legal rhetoric of the times, as well as analyze related legal conflicts between Natives and non-Natives."--Jacket.

results.title: Challenging the secular state : the Islamization of law in modern Indonesia / Arskal Salim.
abstracts: "Challenging the Secular State examines Muslim efforts to incorporate shari'a (religious law) into modern Indonesia's legal system from the time of independence in 1945 to the present. The author argues that attempts to formally implement shari'a in Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim state, have always been marked by tensions between the political aspirations of proponents and opponents of shari'a and by resistance from the national government. As a result, although pro-shari'a movements have made significant progress in recent years, shari'a remains tightly confined within Indonesia's secular legal system. The author first places developments in Indonesia within a broad historical and geographic context, offering a provocative analysis of the Ottoman empire's millet system and thoughtful comparisons of different approaches to pro-shari'a movements in other Muslim countries (Saudi Arabia, Iran, Pakistan). He then describes early aspirations for the formal implementation of shari'a in Indonesia in the context of modern understandings of religious law as conflicting with the idea of the nation-state."--Jacket.

results.title: Borders in cyberspace [electronic resource] : information policy and the global information infrastructure / edited by Brian Kahin and Charles Nesson.
abstracts: Borders in Cyberspace investigates issues arising from national differences in law, public policy, and social and cultural values in light of the emerging global information infrastructure. The contributions include detailed analyses of some of the most visible issues, including intellectual property, security, privacy, and censorship.

results.title: Chinese justice [electronic resource] : civil dispute resolution in contemporary China / edited by Margaret Y.K. Woo, Mary E. Gallagher.
abstracts: "This volume analyzes whether China's thirty years of legal reform have taken root in Chinese society by examining how ordinary citizens are using the legal system in contemporary China. It is an interdisciplinary look at law in action and at legal institutions from the bottom up, that is, beginning with those at the ground level that are using and working in the legal system. It explores the emergent Chinese conception of justice - one that seeks to balance Chinese tradition, socialist legacies, and the needs of the global market. Given the political dimension of dispute resolution in creating, settling, and changing social norms, this volume contributes to a greater understanding of political and social change in China today and of the process of legal reform generally"-- Provided by publisher.

results.title: Fair, square & legal [electronic resource] : safe hiring, managing & firing practices to keep you & your company out of court / Donald H. Weiss.
abstracts: Fair, Square & Legal is a concise, one-stop guide to what you as a manager should and shouldn't do if you want to stay clear of trouble. This revised edition has been thoroughly updated throughout, and provides new coverage of the Family and Medical Leave Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1991, and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Written by an experienced manager, the book translates complex legal issues and precedents into a set of easy-to-follow guidelines for managing people. It provides both an overview of safe managerial procedures and a quick look-up source for specific situations you may encounter. The book encompasses a broad range of potential problem areas. For each, author Donald H. Weiss supplies non-legalese definitions of key terms, practical guidelines for what to say and do, fictionalized stories that illustrate both problems and solutions, and actual case studies of precedent-setting court decisions.

results.title: Working with 401(k) plans [electronic resource] / Glenn Sulzer.

results.title: Current issues in Islamic banking and finance [electronic resource] : resilience and stability in the present system / editor, Angelo M. Venardos.
abstracts: "The phenomenal worldwide development over the past decade of Islamic banking and finance is drawing much attention to Southeast Asia, which, on the platform of its own economic growth success, is also proving to be the gateway for Middle Eastern petrodollar investments into the two great emerging markets of India and China. This book provides a timely examination of the issues confronting this US$300 - US$500 billion market growing at 15% - 20% per annum, with reviews of the different financial markets, be they capital (Sukuk), retail or wealth management. It further includes reviews from the various jurisdictions including Malaysia (the front-runner), Singapore (the regional financial hub), Brunei (an offshore Islamic market player) and the sleeping giant, Indonesia, as well as newly emerging participants such as Japan and the United States. Contributors, all well-known leading practitioners in their fields, range from lawyers, accountants, bankers and educators to policy advisors, and come from institutions such as CIMB, Kuwait Finance House, OCBC Bank and PricewaterhouseCoopers, among others."--Book cover.

results.title: Fish in the lakes, wild rice, and game in abundance [electronic resource] : testimony on behalf of Mille Lacs Ojibwe hunting and fishing rights / James M. McClurken, compiler ; with Charles E. Cleland ... [et al.].
abstracts: "On 13 August 1990 members of the Mille Lacs Band of Ojibwe filed a lawsuit against the State of Minnesota for interfering with the hunting, fishing, and gathering rights that had been guaranteed to them in an 1837 treaty with the United States. In order to interpret the treaty the courts had to consider historical circumstances, the intentions of the parties, and the treaty's implementation. The Mille Lacs Band faced a mammoth challenge.
How does one argue the Native side of the case when all historical documentation was written by non-Natives? The Mille Lacs selected six scholars to testify for them.

Published here for the first time, Charles Cleland, James McClurken, Helen Tanner, John Nichols, Thomas Lund, and Bruce White discuss the circumstances under which the treaty was written, the personalities involved in the negotiations, and the legal rhetoric of the times, as well as analyze related legal conflicts between Natives and non-Natives."--Jacket.
